Have you noticed the similarities between the Fabrilife and Manfare clothing brands?

I first noticed the similarities between Fabrilife and Manfare a few months ago on Daraz. Fabrilife is one of my favorite brands, but I had never tried Manfare before. However, I saw that Manfare was offering almost the same designs as Fabrilife, but at a slightly lower price point. This similarity was not just limited to one product category; it was present across the board, from t-shirts and joggers to shorts and underwear. Even the wallets were similar!

Yesterday, while scrolling through Daraz, I saw that someone had asked if Fabrilife was a sub-brand of Manfare. Fabrilife responded by saying that Manfare always copies their products.

This got me thinking: why doesn't Fabrilife take legal action against Manfare for copying their designs? What do brand practitioners think about this?

In addition to the potential legal and reputational risks, the copying by Manfare could also impact Fabrilife's sales. If customers are confused about which brand is the original, they may be less likely to buy from Fabrilife. This could lead to lost sales for the company.

- Mashrafe

Sanjiv Meta, a renowned business leader in India, recently retired from his position as MD and CEO of Hindustan Unilever. He gained fame for his defense of Unilever Bangladesh.

Sanjeev Mehta is recognized as a global leader in business and leadership insights on LinkedIn.

Interestingly, when Mehta was initially approached to join Unilever Bangladesh (UBL), he was not interested. This was because Unilever was struggling in Bangladesh at the time. Who would want to join a failing business, right?

However, his wife encouraged him by saying, "When else will you have the opportunity to turn around a failing business? If you succeed, it will be a great achievement for you."

In 1998, Mehta joined UBL as a Commercial Director. He successfully turned the failing business around and brought growth. As a result, he was promoted to Chairman and Managing Director of UBL.

From 2002 to 2006, under Mehta's leadership, Unilever Bangladesh became the crown jewel of the parent company.

Mehta's success opened up new opportunities for him. He was appointed CEO in the Philippines, North America, and the Middle East.

Finally, in 2013, he was given the responsibility of leading Hindustan Unilever Limited (HUL), the largest FMCG company in India. Mehta successfully operated the company for ten years, during which HUL's market capitalization increased from $17 billion to $75 billion.

Mehta's success can be attributed to two key factors. Firstly, he believed in investing in himself. He started his career as a Chartered Accountant and joined the Finance Team at Union Carbide (UCC) Chemical Corporation. After the Bhopal gas tragedy, he was appointed to the Crisis Response Team, showcasing his exceptional performance. This led to his transition to the business unit.

Secondly, Mehta emphasized the importance of paying attention to detail. Unlike many CEOs who prefer to stay in their air-conditioned offices, Mehta made it a point to visit the market. During one of his visits to Bhubaneswar, he noticed that the scent of Lux was fading quickly. He immediately informed the R&D team, who discovered that the humidity in the area was causing this issue. This attention to detail also translated into his approach to product development.

Mehta's success serves as an inspiration for aspiring business leaders in our country, where there are numerous successful individuals in the field.
